Description: Fragment of Ionian pottery figure vase (plastic vase) in the form of a helmeted head. Cheekpiece and part of nose and mouth preserved, as well as part of flat base. Mould-made and hollow, with fingerprints on the inside. Traces of a white coating or residue. Very fine orange-brown clay (5YR6/6) with abundant silver mica. Inside grey.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels from Rhodes (British Museum 1860,0201.41; 1836,0224.370;1922,1017.2). This example is made of a micaceous fabric consistent with a South Ionian origin. Helmeted heads were one of the most popular forms found on Rhodes, where large numbers of these bottles have been found. Many were exported over long distances, sometimes as far west as southern Italy and Sicily.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DB.023) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5928 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
